questiontext.text: A mother brought her 6-month-old baby to the Unhas General Hospital with a complaint of a cleft lip since birth. On extra-oral and intra-oral examination, a gap was found on the left lip, and the gums and palate up to the uvula. The correct diagnosis for this case is

According to the principles of flap design, which of the following statements is incorrect?

answer.text: The flap must be larger than the bone deficit
The width of the flap must be adequate, so that the operative field is easily accessible
The base of the flap must have the same width as the free gingival margin, to ensure adequate blood supply and to promote healing
Vertical releasing incisions should begin approximately at the buccal vestibule and end at the interdental papillae of the gingiv
The flap should be without tension and trauma during manipulation

answer.text: The apex of the tooth that is still closed

questiontext.text: Local factors affecting alveolar ridge resorption include:

answer.text: localized trauma associated with loss of alveolar bone, Denture wearing
alveoloplasty techniques used at the time of tooth removal, localized trauma associated with loss of alveolar bone, Denture wearing
localized trauma associated with loss of alveolar bone
alveoloplasty techniques used at the time of tooth removal

questiontext.text: In the surgical procedure of transplantation, tissue healing process plays an important role. The following aspects are important in transplantation, namely:

answer.text: Does not require suturing, to minimize trauma to the gingiva.
Using a lot of local anesthetic to improve vascularization
Creation of semilunar flaps, to maximize vascularity

questiontext.text: Variations in facial structure may contribute to resorption patterns because

answer.text: Individuals with low mandibular plane angles and more acute gonial angles are capable of generating lower bite force, thereby placing less pressure on the alveolar ridge areas
Individuals with low mandibular plane angles and more acute gonial angles are capable of generating higher bite force, thereby placing greater pressure on the alveolar ridge areas
The radiographic volume of bone present in the alveolar ridges is the same in all facial forms
The actual volume of bone present in the alveolar ridges is the same in all facial forms
Individuals with low mandibular plane angles and more acute gonial angles are capable of generating lower bite force, thereby placing greater pressure on the alveolar ridge areas

questiontext.text: Radiographic modalities play an important role in pre and post operative transplantation, these modalities are the exception.
Best denture support the following characteristics:

answer.text: No bony or soft tissue protuberances or undercuts
Movable soft tissue on denture bearing area
Alveolar processes that are large and of the proper configuration (The ideal shape of the alveolar process is a broad V-shaped ridge)
Evidence of intraoral or extraoral pathologic conditions
Proper interarch jaw relationship in the anteroposterior dimensions only.

questiontext.text: In the immature apex, the main considerations to be considered for the success of the transplant process are.
The indications for the transplant procedure are:
Evaluation of supporting soft tissue of the primary denture-bearing area overlying the alveolar ridge includes:

answer.text: Tissue at the depth of the vestibule should not be supple

By relaxing the soft tissue adjacent to the area of the alveolar ridge, the dentist can note muscle or soft tissue attachments (including frena) that approximate the crest of the alveolar ridge and are often responsible for the loss of peripheral seal of the denture during speech and mastication
Percussion discloses hypermobile fibrous tissue that is inadequate for a stable denture base

The lingual aspect of the mandible should be inspected to determine the level of attachment of the mylohyoid muscle in relation to the crest of the mandibular ridge and the attachment of the genioglossus muscle in the anterior mandible.

questiontext.text: Before taking action on a patient, a dentist will provide an informed concern to the patient about the risks and consequences, both good and bad, in an action procedure. The worst thing that must be explained if there is extensive resorption of the apex of the donor tooth and loose, then the steps to be taken are
Before any surgical intervention, a treatment plan addressing the patient’s identified oral problems should be formulated. This involves several considerations, such as:

answer.text: Short-term maintenance of the underlying bone, soft tissue, and prosthetic appliances
Hasty treatment planning can often result in necessary loss of bone or soft tissue and proper functioning of the prosthetic appliance
In an extremely young patient who has undergone the same degree of atrophy, bony augmentation procedures may be not indicated.
In an older patient in whom high bony resorption has taken place, soft tissue surgery alone may be sufficient for improved prosthesis function

make incision for flap reflection
allow adequate visualization and access to the alveolar ridge
remove the major portion of the jaw sharp area

questiontext.text: The following are very important factors that affect the success of replantation measures:

A 20-year-old female patient came to the General Hospital with a history of being hit by a rickshaw, and fell down, tooth 21 fell out of the socket but did not fall to the ground about 10 minutes ago. Actions that can be taken for successful treatment are
Which is the incorrect statement in treating an abnormal lingual frenal attachment?

answer.text: Inferior alveolar nerve block provide adequate anesthesia for a lingual frenectomy

Surgical release of the lingual frenum requires incising the attachment of the mucosa and fibrous connective tissue at the base of tongue in a transverse fashion to prevent dissection into the floor of the mouth and damage to adjacent anatomic structures such as the lingual vessels, nerve, and submandibular ducts.
An abnormal lingual frenal attachment usually consists of mucosa, dense fibrous connective tissue, and, occasionally, superior fibers of the genioglossus muscle.
Incisions are done with care due to presence of lingual blood vessels
After loss of teeth, this frenal attachment interferes with denture stability, because each time the tongue is moved, the frenal attachment is tensed and the denture is dislodged.

questiontext.text: The incorrect indication of pre-prosthetic surgery is:

answer.text: Uneven alveolar processes, but no detrimental effect on denture stability
Presence of malignant neoplasm on patients about to undergo radiotherapy
Presence of palatal Torus or Mandibular Torus

answer.text: Does not irritate the pulp and periodontal tissues

questiontext.text: Teeth that do not erupt in time are known as _______.

answer.text: Malposed teeth

questiontext.text: Post-replantation instructions conveyed to the patient, do not include the following, viz.

answer.text: Do not use the replanted tooth for biting/chewing

questiontext.text: Which of the following is the incorrect etiology of impacted teeth?

answer.text: Gradual evolutionary reduction of the human jaw size

questiontext.text: Based on the relationship of the impacted maxillary third molar with the maxillary sinus, what does NSA (no sinus approximation) mean?

answer.text: there is 2 mm or more of bone between the impacted tooth and the maxillary sinus
there is 3 mm or more of bone between the impacted tooth and the maxillary sinus
There is no bone or there is a thin layer of bone between the adjacent tooth and the maxillary sinus
there is 4 mm or more of bone between the impacted tooth and the maxillary sinus
There is no bone or there is a thin layer of bone between the impacted tooth and the maxillary sinus

questiontext.text: Maxillary third molar impaction can be classified based on:

answer.text: the longitudinal axis of the impacted maxillary third molar in relation to the axis of the maxillary first molar
the relationship of the impacted mandibular third molar to the retromolar pad
the depth of impaction compared to the second molar
the relationship of the impacted maxillary third molar with the zygomatic bone
the relation of the root/apex curvature of the impacted tooth to the maxillary sinus

questiontext.text: Which of the following are reasons for removing an impacted tooth?

answer.text: Asymptomatic full bony impaction in a 65-year-old patient
Prevention of periodontal disease in a tooth adjacent to the impacted tooth
Prevention of pericoronitis and periodontal disease in a tooth adjacent to the impacted tooth

Intraoral examination showed tooth 18 is in a buccoversion position, at approximately the same level as the occlusal surface of the second molar. According to Archer, what is the classification of this impacted tooth?

In the case of an impacted tooth, the technique of removing the tooth by splitting the tooth is called

On clinical examination, it was seen that the mesial crown of tooth 38 was below the crown of tooth 37. Radiographic examination showed that the distance between the distal tooth 37 and the mandibular ramus was wide enough for the mesiodistal of tooth 38, and the crown of tooth 38 was above the cervical line of tooth 37. The diagnosis that can be made from the above case is:

answer.text: Streptococci and a large variety of aerobic bacteria
repeated trauma from a maxillary first molar

questiontext.text: All impacted teeth should be removed unless specific contraindications justify leaving them in position. When the potential benefits outweigh the potential complications and risks, the procedure should be performed. Similarly, when the risks are greater than the potential benefits, the procedure should be deferred. The following states the contraindications for impacted teeth removal, except

answer.text: Probable Excessive Damage to Adjacent Structures

questiontext.text: The ease of removing an impacted tooth depends on its accessibility. To gain access to the area and to visualize the overlying bone that must be removed, the surgeon must reflect an adequate mucoperiosteal flap. What is the preferred flap to remove impacted teeth?
According to Berger, one of the local etiology of impacted teeth is:
Which is the incorrect statement about the procedure of impacted teeth removal?

answer.text: The amount of bone that must be removed varies with the depth of the impaction, the morphology of the roots, and the angulation of the tooth.
No bone is removed from the lingual aspect so as to protect the lingual nerve from injury.
The bone on the occlusal aspect and on the buccal and distal aspects, down to the cervical line of the impacted tooth, should be removed initially
Sectioning allows portions of the tooth to be removed separately with elevators through the opening provided by bone removal
Tooth sectioning is performed with a chisel, and the tooth is sectioned three fourths of the way toward the lingual aspect.

questiontext.text: What is the radiography appearance of jaw cyst

answer.text: Mixed radiopaque and radiolucency with unclear margin
Unclear radiolucency in the periapical of tooth
